Home
Support the Festival
Support the Festival
Thanks to our community, the Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival is planning its 26th Annual Festival! We need your continued support to grow and provide enhanced cultural enrichment activities to the community.
You can help support the festival by using any of the following methods below:
PayPal Giving Fund:
www.PayPal.com/us/fundraiser/charity/111812
Amazon Smile:
https://smile.amazon.com
Make a Donation
100 4 $100 Campaign:
https://givebutter.com/tbbhf1004100
Become a Sponsor
end .entry
Comments are closed.

The Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival is the largest African-American event in the bay area and has been selected as one of the Top 20 Events by the Southeast Tourism Society six times, during it’s tenure. Please click the “
Donate Now
” and help us continue our cause.

Noscript content for added SEO

The Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival (TBBHF/The Festival) is an annual cultural event that features speakers, musicians, artists, poets and craftspeople locally and nationally. The festival traditionally begins the week-end before the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. holiday and extends through the month of April. It’s programming promotes education and cultural sensitivity. Each signature event provides both children and adults with an opportunity to increase their awareness of African and African-American culture and history. This event strives to increase the arts and cultural experiences of its diaspora.
Mission
The purpose of the Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival, Inc. is to offer the community of Tampa Bay a unique blend of African and African American art, culture and history, therefore serving as a conduit for promoting and perpetuating the art, culture and history of African Americans and African people for the benefit of all Tampa Bay residents and tourists to the Tampa Bay area. It exists to support the culturally rich Tampa Bay communities by ensuring all events are inclusive of the entire community.
Board Members
The TBBHF board consists of individuals from the Tampa Bay community who participate in organizing the festival and other events throughout the year serving the Tampa Bay community. To view our Board of Directors, click
here
.
Annual Festival
The Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival (TBBHF) is Southwest Florida’s premier cultural event organized by the Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival, a 501 c3, Florida non-profit corporation. This annual, family friendly, cultural experience focuses on education, health and wellness, music, economic and social empowerment and the arts. The 2-Day Music Fest, which takes place in April and features local and nationally, recognized musicians, artists, poets, and craftspeople.

Have a question? Send us a message.
Email us with any questions or inquiries or call us at the number provided and we would be happy to answer your questions.
Please allow up to 24 to 48 hours for us to respond. We appreciate your time and will respond as soon as possible.

Partner Events
Listed below are Partnership Events throughout the community taking place during the 10-day Festival.   These events are open the entire community and are filled with educational experiences that recognize the Black diaspora.  Read more to get a preview of these upcoming events.

Noscript content for added SEO

Dr. Samuel Wright, Sr
Founder
The Festival’s founder, Dr. Samuel Lamar Wright, Sr. and the Tampa Bay Convention and Visitors Bureau, a major contributor, had a vision to raise awareness of the African and African-American heritage within the Tampa Bay Area and surrounding community. The result of their combined efforts was increased exposure to African and African-American culture through positive images and achievements.
Ruby Jackson
Chairperson & Events Coordinator
Ruby Jackson is a recent retired senior human resource business partner at the University of South Florida, where she worked for more than three decades in the College of Education. She is looking forward to celebrating the next phase of her life. A native of Tampa and a mother of two sons, a daugther-in-law and four grandchildren.  Ruby has dedicated years of engagement in the community where she was born and raised.
Williams Sanders
Chairperson & Entertainment Coordinator
William is the Founder of Unlimited Gospel Expressions and a Gospel Music Historian. He has been involved with the Tampa Bay Black Heritage Festival since the beginning and he has been instrumental in incorporating the Gospel components while actively helping to coordinate other Festival events. He is active in his church, the Tampa Bay religious community and has been a Festival Chairperson since 2010.
Ivy Box
Marketing Coordinator
Ivy is a Florida native of Haitian descent, who was actively involved with the Festival for a decade before joining the Board.  She brings her experiences in the corporate, entertainment, and philanthropic industries where she has cultivated a niche of bridging the intergenerational gap through marketing. Ivy is a marketing professional, author, community leader, and philanthropist who believes that the sky is not the limit; it is only the beginning.
Connie Hicks
Sponsorship Coordinator
Connie is a native of Kingsport, TN but has called Florida her home for the past 34 years. She has always been an advocate for community service and encourages her children to be advocates as well. Connie joined the board in 2012 to bring her expertise and enthusiasm to the sponsorship and gala committees. Connie is currently employed by Florida Blue which supports and also encourages her volunteer efforts.
David Hall
Logistics Coordinator
David Hall, a native of Munich, Germany, by way of Pemberton, New Jersey, is a General Manager and Senior Estimator for a large construction company.  While in school, he studied Architectural Design and won several awards from the State of New Jersey for his drawings. David Hall is a proud father, former engineer, and former restaurateur of several successful restaurants and lounges.
Robert West
Director
Robert R. West, Jr. is the Community Development Manager of Central & North Florida for TD Bank and an adjunct business professor. Mr. West specializes in consulting diverse communities on the lending opportunities for home ownership and small business & commercial banking solutions.  Mr. West’s Veteran status includes 5 years in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve as a combat engineer and 3 years active duty as a recruiter.  Mr. West separated from the Marine Corps with the rank of Staff Sergeant (E-6).
Michael Spears
Director
Michael is a native on New Jersey and has been located in Tampa for the last 10 years. Michael is passionate about bringing awareness to the Black and African American community. Casting a wide net teaching and bringing awareness to Black History and customs through
ongoing
contact with all local communities.
Jarvis Meeks
Director
Jarvis Meeks, a Florida native, is an experienced educator in middle school mathematics. He began his career in architecture after graduating from Tuskegee University. After several years of practicing architecture. He later received his Master’s in Business Administration from the University of Phoenix.
Meeks has served as a member on several boards such as the SAC Committee, The Lake Wales Arts Council along with various other civic and religious organizations.
